questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of altered mental status for 1 day. He has also had headaches, severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 days. He has hypertension, insomnia, and bipolar disorder. His medications include lisinopril, fluoxetine, atorvastatin, lithium, olanzapine, and alprazolam. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg. He is somnolent and confused. His mucous membranes are dry. Neurological examination shows dysarthria, decreased muscle strength in all extremities, and a coarse tremor of the hands bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to intravenous fluid administration and electrolyte supplementation, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whole bowel irrigation (WBI) with polyethylene glycol solution can be effective in the acute setting when patients ingest large amounts of lithium. It is recommended for asymptomatic patients who are awake and present shortly (within 4 hours) after presumed ingestion. WBI is not recommended in symptomatic patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is used to treat serotonin syndrome, which may develop following therapy with a serotonergic drug such as fluoxetine. Serotonin syndrome can result in an altered mental status, tremor, tachypnea, and diarrhea. However, other clinical features such as hyperreflexia, clonus, rigidity, hyperthermia, hypertension, and tachycardia would also be present. The mucous membranes of the oral cavity are usually moist (due to sialorrhea) and the pupils would be dilated. Moreover, serotonin syndrome usually occurs within 24 hours of an increase in the dose and/or the addition of a serotonergic drug; there is no history of a recent change in the patient's medications.

C) CORRECT:

Hemodialysis is indicated for the treatment of lithium toxicity in patients with an altered mental status, seizures, and/or life-threatening arrhythmias. Other indications for hemodialysis include a serum lithium concentration > 5.0 mEq/L or > 4.0 mEq/L with evidence of renal dysfunction (serum creatinine > 2.0 mg/dL). Serum lithium concentration should be measured in all patients with suspected lithium toxicity at the time of presentation and it should be repeated at close intervals (initially every 2–4 hours) to monitor the therapeutic effects of fluid administration and hemodialysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines such as diazepam may be used to treat seizures that occur in patients with lithium intoxication. This patient does not have a history of seizures; a different therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene may be used to treat severe neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), which may occur following therapy with lithium or olanzapine. NMS can result in an altered mental status and tachypnea. However, other clinical features, such as hyperthermia, rigidity, hypertension, tachycardia, and/or diaphoresis, would also be present.
questions.hint: This patient takes lithium and has likely become dehydrated (due to severe vomiting and diarrhea for the past 2 days), which predisposes him to acute lithium toxicity. Lithium toxicity manifests with neurological symptoms (altered mental status, dysarthria, decreased muscle strength, coarse tremor). In addition, patients with lithium toxicity commonly present with gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea), which can further exacerbate dehydration.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of daytime sleepiness and a dry mouth. She says her sleepiness is due to getting up to urinate several times each night. During this time, she has also had increased thirst. She currently drinks up to 20 cups of water daily. She does not feel a sudden urge prior to urinating and has not had dysuria. She has a history of multiple urinary tract infections and head trauma following a suicide attempt 3 months ago. She has bipolar I disorder and hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Examination shows poor skin turgor. Mucous membranes are dry. Expiratory wheezes are heard over both lung fields. There is no suprapubic tenderness. She describes her mood as “good” and her affect is appropriate. Neurologic examination shows tremor in both hands. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 151 mEq/L and an elevated antidiuretic hormone concentration. Urine osmolality is 124 mOsm/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Hypothalamic injury can result in central DI with low ADH levels. However, this patient's elevated ADH levels suggests nephrogenic DI.

B) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic syndrome has a wide array of clinical manifestations. Elevated ADH levels due to exogenous secretion in patients with paraneoplastic syndrome results in syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) which, unlike the condition in this patient, manifests as excessive free water retention, euvolemic hyponatremia, and high urine osmolality. The elevated ADH levels in this patient are, therefore, more likely due to another cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Pituitary tumors and subsequent hypothalamic injury can result in central DI with low ADH levels. However, this patient's elevated ADH levels suggests nephrogenic DI.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with psychogenic polydipsia (PP) present with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality levels. However, PP causes suppressed release of ADH, low serum Na+, and low serum osmolality levels due to the dilutional effect of excessive water intake. Furthermore, patients with PP do not have dehydration like this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism can be asymptomatic or manifest with symptoms of hypokalemia such as headache, muscle weakness, and polyuria. Secondary hypertension, low or normal serum K+, and metabolic alkalosis may also be seen. In nephrogenic DI, which this patient has, the volume contraction resulting from excessive water loss results in increased activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), causing secondary hyperaldosteronism.

F) CORRECT:

Nephrogenic DI is the most common complication of long-term use of lithium, the first-line mood stabilizer for patients with bipolar disorder, as is the case here. Lithium is believed to cause nephrogenic DI by interfering with ADH signaling in the collecting duct cells, which results in reduced expression of water channel aquaporin-2 (AQP2) in these cells and subsequently an elevated ADH in an attempt to compensate.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).
questions.hint: This patient has signs of diabetes insipidus (DI): polyuria, polydipsia, nocturia, dehydration, increased serum Na+, and decreased urine osmolality.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate because of unusual behavior and incoherent talkativeness for the past week. Her roommate reports that the patient has been rearranging the furniture in her room at night and has ordered a variety of expensive clothes online. The patient says she feels “better than ever” and has a lot of energy. She had a depressive episode 1 year ago. She had absence seizures as a child and remembers that valproate was discontinued because it damaged her liver. She takes no medication. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Her pulse is 78/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 122/60 mm Hg. Mental status examination shows lack of insight, affective lability, and pressured speech with flight of ideas. Urine toxicology screening is negative. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Prior to prescribing long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient, it is most appropriate to obtain which of the following additional tests?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum transaminases are a side effect of valproate, which is used as long-term treatment for bipolar disorder and as first-line therapy for acute mania in bipolar disorder. Liver function tests should be performed prior to and throughout treatment with valproate. Given this patient's history of valproate-induced hepatotoxicity after treatment of absence seizures, lithium (which is metabolized and excreted renally) should be considered instead.

B) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis is a potential side effect of carbamazepine and valproate, both of which may be used as long-term treatment for bipolar disorder. Carbamazepine can further cause aplastic anemia while valproate can lead to thrombocytopenia. Therefore, complete blood count (CBC) should be performed prior to and throughout pharmacotherapy. However, carbamazepine is considered an alternative agent, and given this patient's history of valproate-induced hepatotoxicity after treatment of absence seizures, lithium is preferred. Monitoring CBC is not necessary prior to or during lithium therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Lithium is the preferred long-term treatment of patients with bipolar disorder and those experiencing an acute manic episode. The use of lithium is limited by numerous adverse effects. For example, it can induce or worsen preexisting hypothyroidism by blocking the production and release of L-thyroxine. In addition, lithium is a teratogen and it is associated with an increased risk of congenital heart defects, such as Ebstein anomaly. Other adverse effects include lithium nephropathy, cardiotoxicity (e.g., T-wave depressions, sinus node dysfunction), and lithium-induced hyperparathyroidism, which can lead to hypercalcemia. Therefore, thyroid and kidney function as well as calcium levels should be assessed, and pregnancy should be ruled out prior to treatment. ECG should be obtained in patients with risk factors for atherosclerosis. Because lithium has a narrow therapeutic window, serum lithium concentrations should be closely monitored during treatment.

Lithium takes ∼ 5 days to achieve steady blood levels; therefore, an antipsychotic and/or benzodiazepine may be given as concomitant therapy in patients with an acute manic episode.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia is a potential side effect of second generation antipsychotics, which can be used as alternative agents in the long-term treatment of bipolar disorder. However, serum prolactin levels are obtained during rather than before treatment. Moreover, lithium is the preferred maintenance therapy option.

E) INCORRECT:

Metabolic side effects, such as dyslipidemia, are common in second generation antipsychotics, which can be used as alternative agents in the long-term treatment of bipolar disorder. However, lipid studies are obtained during rather than before treatment. Moreover, lithium is the preferred maintenance therapy for bipolar disorder.
questions.hint: This patient has an elevated mood, increased energy, affective lability, and pressured speech with flight of ideas, strongly suggesting an acute manic episode of bipolar disorder, for which long-term treatment with lithium is indicated.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency room because of confusion. His wife says he has been urinating more frequently than usual for the past 3 days. He has not had fever or dysuria. He has bipolar disorder, for which he takes lithium. His pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 14/min. He is lethargic and oriented only to person. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and increased capillary refill time. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 158 mEq/L and an antidiuretic hormone (ADH) concentration of 8 pg/mL (N = 1–5). Which of the following is the most likely site of dysfunction in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection, ischemia, and injury of the posterior pituitary gland can result in ADH deficiency, which is the underlying cause of central diabetes insipidus. Although this patient has signs of diabetes insipidus, he has an increased serum ADH concentration, which is more consistent with a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection, inflammation, and malignancy of the hypothalamus can impair ADH synthesis in the supraoptic nucleus, resulting in ADH deficiency and subsequent central diabetes insipidus. Although this patient has signs of diabetes insipidus, he has an increased serum ADH concentration, which is more consistent with a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

C) INCORRECT:

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is caused by an impaired response to ADH in the kidneys. Although the main function of the descending loop of Henle is to concentrate the urine, its cells do not express ADH receptors and are thus not the site of dysfunction that causes nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

D) CORRECT:

Lithium interferes with ADH signaling in principal cells of the collecting duct, thus reducing the expression of aquaporins and impairing the kidney's ability to concentrate urine. This effect results in renal free water loss, which manifests as frequent urination of hypotonic urine, hypernatremia, and dehydration. Reduced extracellular fluid volume and increased serum osmolarity stimulate ADH secretion, which results in an increased serum ADH concentration.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

E) INCORRECT:

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is caused by an impaired response to ADH in the kidneys. The juxtaglomerular apparatus is involved in the regulation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. However, it is not involved in the production or secretion of ADH or response of the kidneys to this hormone.
questions.hint: Polyuria and elevated ADH levels are consistent with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, an adverse effect of lithium therapy.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with bipolar I disorder and hypertension comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of increased thirst, urinary frequency, and sleep disturbance. He says that he now drinks up to 30 cups of water daily. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Examination shows decreased skin turgor. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 149 mEq/L, a potassium concentration of 4.1 mEq/L, and an elevated antidiuretic hormone concentration. His urine osmolality is 121 mOsm/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic polydipsia (PP) can occur during an acute bipolar psychosis and would present with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality levels, all of which this patient has. However, water intoxication from PP would cause hyponatremia and low serum osmolality levels, due to the dilutional effects, and subsequently low ADH levels. Furthermore, patients with PP would not have features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor).

B) CORRECT:

Increased serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in a patient with features of diabetes insipidus is suggestive of a nephrogenic cause. Nephrogenic DI is the most common complication of long-term use of lithium, the first-line mood stabilizer for patients with bipolar disorder. Lithium is believed to cause nephrogenic DI by interfering with ADH signaling in the collecting duct cells, which results in reduced expression of water channel aquaporin-2 in these cells.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

C) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Destruction of the posterior pituitary gland or the hypothalamic stalk by a large pituitary tumor can result in features of diabetes insipidus. However, this would lead to decreased ADH levels, indicating central diabetes insipidus, rather than increased ADH levels, suggesting nephrogenic DI, as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for both small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung. SCLC can cause high ADH levels due to SIADH, but patients with SIADH would have hyponatremia and a high urine osmolality. Polydipsia, polyuria, hypernatremia, and a low urine osmolality would not be expected. SCCs of the lung can secrete PTHrP, which can, in turn, result in hypercalcemia with subsequent neuropsychiatric disturbances and nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, the neuropsychiatric disturbance would usually be acute or subacute, unlike this patient's chronic psychiatric disorder. Moreover, this patient does not have a cough or a history of weight loss that would suggest a pulmonary malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

A tumor in the adrenal cortex can cause primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome), which may lead to hypertension and, occasionally, mild hypernatremia (145–150 mEq/L). However, on its own, primary hyperaldosteronism would not cause polyuria, polydipsia, or features of dehydration such as decreased skin turgor. Hypokalemia caused by primary hyperaldosteronism can desensitize the renal tubules to ADH and, consequently, lead to mild nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, this patient's potassium levels are normal.
questions.hint: This patient has features of diabetes insipidus (DI): polyuria, polydipsia, dehydration, hypernatremia, and decreased urine osmolality (< 300 mOsmol/kg).

questions.text: Ten days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-minute episode of myoclonic jerking movements and urinary incontinence. After regaining consciousness, the patient has no recollection of what happened and seems confused. He has bipolar disorder, which has been controlled with lithium maintenance therapy for the past 15 years, as well as hypertension, asthma, and chronic lower back pain. His pulse is 92/min and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry oral mucosa, muscle fasciculations, and bilateral coarse hand tremor. His speech is slow and he is disoriented. Which of the following is most likely to be the new medication that precipitated this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid overdose can cause altered mental status and myoclonic movements. However, it is unlikely to cause myoclonic seizures because it is an anticonvulsant. Additionally, valproic acid undergoes hepatic clearance and, while it inhibits other medications that are metabolized with the CYP450 system, it does not interfere with the renal excretion of lithium. Therefore, valproic acid is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Advanced acetaminophen toxicity can lead to changes in mental status due to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause myoclonic movements that may be confused for a myoclonic seizure. There is no evidence, however, that this patient consumed high doses of acetaminophen, and he does not have other features of advanced acetaminophen toxicity, such as jaundice or bleeding diathesis. Acetaminophen undergoes hepatic clearance, does not interfere with renal excretion and reabsorption of lithium, and is not known to precipitate lithium toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Theophylline toxicity can cause neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures and tremors) and while it may exclusively manifest with neurologic symptoms, other features (e.g., tachycardia, arrhythmias) are also commonly seen. Additionally, theophylline is not routinely prescribed for asthma due to the risk of toxicity. Finally, since theophylline increases renal clearance and decreases serum concentrations of lithium, it is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity. This patient's symptoms are more likely to result from lithium toxicity following the prescription of more commonly used medication.

D) INCORRECT:

Concurrent use of fluoxetine and lithium increases the risk of developing serotonin syndrome, which can result in myoclonus, altered mental status, and, in severe cases, seizures. However, serotonin syndrome typically develops within hours of initiating or increasing the dose of a precipitating drug and would be unlikely in this patient, who presents 10 days after starting a new medication. Additionally, fluoxetine undergoes hepatic clearance and, while it inhibits other medications that are metabolized with the CYP450 system, it does not interfere with the renal excretion of lithium. Therefore, fluoxetine is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity.

E) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors, such as enalapril, cause vasodilation of the efferent arterioles and a subsequent decrease in GFR, which can lead to renal impairment. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window, and any cause of renal impairment (e.g., chronic kidney disease, NSAID use) or volume depletion (e.g., due to diuretic therapy, cardiovascular disease) can precipitate lithium toxicity. Older patients (> 65 years of age) are particularly at risk for lithium toxicity, given their overall lower decreased glomerular filtration rate. To ensure safety, frequent monitoring of lithium levels is recommended in all patients taking lithium, particularly when starting a new medication.
questions.hint: The introduction of a new medication alongside maintenance therapy with lithium has resulted in this patient developing lithium toxicity, which can cause myoclonic seizures, altered mental status, coarse tremors, and neuromuscular excitability.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of trembling hands and fingers. He noticed that the trembling increases after drinking coffee, and since then he has begun restricting his consumption of caffeinated beverages. He also has mild nausea but no vomiting or diarrhea. One month ago, the patient was diagnosed with bipolar disorder after developing a manic episode and was hospitalized for treatment with lithium. The manic symptoms resolved with pharmacotherapy and he was discharged after 2 weeks. He has not had any difficulty with his activities of daily living since his discharge. The patient has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and two major depressive episodes. His mother died by suicide when he was 5 years old. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes per week and does not drink alcohol. Current medications are insulin and lithium. The patient is alert and oriented. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination does not show any abnormal movements at rest. When the patient is asked to extend his arms in front of his body, a fine tremor is seen in the hands and fingers bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A fingerstick glucose test shows no abnormalities. Serum lithium concentration is 0.5 mEq/L (N = 0.4–1.0). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Decrease the total daily dose of lithium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If serum lithium concentration is in the standard (0.60–0.80 mEq/L) or high (0.80–1.00 mEq/L) therapeutic range, decreasing the total daily lithium dose to the minimum effective dose is an appropriate strategy to decrease side effects. In this patient, however, the serum lithium concentration is in the low therapeutic range (0.40–0.60 mEq/L); a further decrease in the total daily lithium dose would impair therapeutic efficacy. Additionally, mild nausea and a postural tremor are side effects that can be managed by other means.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis is indicated for the treatment of lithium intoxication if the patient has an altered mental status, seizures, severe arrhythmias, and/or a serum lithium concentration > 5.0 mEq/L (> 4.0 mEq/L if the patient has concomitant renal insufficiency). While lithium toxicity usually occurs with serum lithium concentrations > 1.5 mEq/L, this patient's serum lithium concentration is within the reference range. Additionally, lithium intoxication manifests with a coarse, irregular tremor rather than a postural fine tremor, and gastrointestinal manifestations of lithium toxicity are usually more severe and include vomiting and diarrhea rather than mild nausea.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid, a mood stabilizer, can be used for maintenance therapy in bipolar disorder if the side effects of lithium cannot be tolerated by the patient even at the lowest possible dose. However, mild nausea and the lithium-induced postural tremor, as seen here, are not indications for switching from lithium to another mood stabilizer; these particular adverse effects of lithium therapy can be controlled by other means. In bipolar disorder, the mood stabilizer that successfully treated a patient's manic episode (in this case, lithium) should be continued as maintenance therapy unless otherwise indicated.

D) CORRECT:

In many patients, both nausea and the lithium-induced postural tremor decrease over time; most cases are therefore managed conservatively with reassurance, avoidance of exacerbating factors (e.g., caffeine, stress), and follow-up. If the tremor persists, a reduction in the total daily dose of lithium (if serum lithium concentration is close to the upper limit of the therapeutic range), the use of short-acting lithium preparations, and/or divided doses (to reduce peak serum lithium concentrations) can be considered. If the tremor is severe or refractory to expectant management and dosage adjustment, beta blockers (e.g., propranolol), which are also used to treat other forms of postural tremors (e.g., essential tremor, physiologic tremor), can be used. If the tremor is progressive, coarse, irregular, affects parts of the body besides the upper limbs, and/or accompanies other symptoms (e.g., delirium, diarrhea, vomiting), lithium intoxication must be ruled out. Nausea can be reduced by advising the patient to take lithium during or immediately after meals, use of a sustained-release preparation of lithium, and/or divided doses.

The differential diagnosis for the lithium-induced postural tremor includes benign essential tremor, Parkinson disease, drug-induced parkinsonism (e.g., due to antipsychotic therapy, often used as an adjunct to a mood stabilizer during the acute manic episode), and metabolic abnormalities (e.g., hypoglycemia).

E) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers such as propranolol are only indicated for the management of a lithium-induced postural tremor if the tremor is severe (i.e., causes functional or social impairment for the patient) or is refractory to other steps. Beta blockers have been reported to decrease renal lithium clearance and are therefore not used as first-line therapy for lithium-induced postural tremors. A different step is more appropriate for the initial management of this patient.
questions.hint: Approx. 25% of patients on lithium develop a symmetric, nonprogressive, fine (approx. 10 Hz) postural tremor in the distal ends of the upper extremities. This type of tremor typically occurs when lithium therapy is started or the dose is increased but can occur at any time during the course of treatment. Nausea is also a common side effect, occurring in 10–20% of patients on lithium.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents with polyuria, nocturia, and polydipsia. She has bipolar disorder that has been treated with lithium for 20 years. Her medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she is not taking any other medications or using recreational drugs. Her vital signs and physical examination are within normal limits.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Sodium (mEq/liter)
145
136–145



Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.8
3.5–5.0


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
22
21–30


Chloride (mEq/liter)
113
98–106


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
24
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.5
0.6–1.1


Random glucose (mg/dL)
150
<140


Her 24-hour measured urine output is 6.1 liters, and her urine osmolality is 60 mOsm/kg (reference ranges vary with intake).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely to explain this patient’s current symptoms?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic polydipsia causes polyuria and dilute urine, but it is associated with a serum sodium level on the low end of normal or even hyponatremia, whereas the serum sodium in this patient is at the upper limit of normal.

B) INCORRECT:

The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion is associated with hyponatremia and small volume of inappropriately concentrated urine.

C) INCORRECT:

Central diabetes insipidus causes symptoms similar to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus but can be distinguished from nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by evaluating the response of the kidney to desmopressin. Given this patient's history of long-standing lithium use, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is a much more likely diagnosis than central diabetes insipidus.

D) INCORRECT:

Type 2 diabetes can cause polyuria and polydipsia; however, this manifests as a solute diuresis with a higher urinary osmolality. Although this patient's random glucose level is higher than normal at 150 mg/dL, it does not confirm a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes. Confirmation requires a random plasma glucose concentration ≥200 mg/dL in the presence of symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms are most likely from the development of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Chronic lithium ingestion affects the principal cells of the collecting ducts, which can lead to resistance to antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, which may be irreversible. Symptoms of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus include polyuria (arbitrarily defined as urine output >3 liters daily) and polydipsia. Nocturia is common, and most patients also drink fluid during the night when they rise to urinate because they cannot tolerate a prolonged period without fluid intake. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus develops in up to 40% of patients treated with lithium. Patients with diabetes insipidus have intact thirst and usually compensate for the water diuresis by drinking large volumes of fluid. These patients typically have serum sodium values at the high end of normal, as seen in this case. When patients with diabetes insipidus are asked to restrict fluid intake for medical procedures, severe hypernatremia may result.

Key learning point: Hypernatremia in a lithium-treated patient is most likely to be caused by nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate because of unusual behavior for the past week. Her roommate reports that the patient has been rearranging the furniture in her room at night and has ordered a variety of expensive clothes online, hindering the patient's ability to pay rent. The patient says she feels “better than ever”. She had a depressive episode 1 year ago. She had absence seizures as a child and remembers that valproate was discontinued because it damaged her liver. Mental status examination shows pressured speech with flight of ideas. Urine toxicology screening and pregnancy test are negative. Prior to prescribing long-term pharmacotherapy for this patient, it is most appropriate to obtain which of the following additional tests?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum transaminases are a side effect of valproate, which is used as long-term treatment for bipolar disorder and as first-line therapy for acute mania in bipolar disorder. Liver function tests should be performed prior to and throughout treatment with valproate. Given this patient's history of valproate-induced hepatotoxicity after treatment of absence seizures, lithium (which is metabolized and excreted renally) should be considered instead.

B) INCORRECT:

Agranulocytosis is a potential side effect of carbamazepine and valproate, both of which may be used as long-term treatment for bipolar disorder. Carbamazepine can further cause aplastic anemia while valproate can lead to thrombocytopenia. Therefore, complete blood count (CBC) should be performed prior to and throughout pharmacotherapy. However, carbamazepine is considered an alternative agent, and given this patient's history of valproate-induced hepatotoxicity after treatment of absence seizures, lithium is preferred. Monitoring CBC is not necessary prior to or during lithium therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Lithium is the preferred long-term treatment of patients with bipolar disorder and those experiencing an acute manic episode. The use of lithium is limited by numerous adverse effects. For example, it can induce or worsen preexisting hypothyroidism by blocking the production and release of L-thyroxine. In addition, lithium is a teratogen and it is associated with an increased risk of congenital heart defects, such as Ebstein anomaly. Other adverse effects include lithium nephropathy, cardiotoxicity (e.g., T-wave depressions, sinus node dysfunction), and lithium-induced hyperparathyroidism, which can lead to hypercalcemia. Therefore, thyroid and kidney function as well as calcium levels should be assessed, and pregnancy should be ruled out prior to treatment. ECG should be obtained in patients with risk factors for atherosclerosis. Because lithium has a narrow therapeutic window, serum lithium concentrations should be closely monitored during treatment.

Lithium takes ∼ 5 days to achieve steady blood levels; therefore, an antipsychotic and/or benzodiazepine may be given as concomitant therapy in patients with an acute manic episode.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia is a potential side effect of second generation antipsychotics, which can be used as alternative agents in the long-term treatment of bipolar disorder. However, serum prolactin levels are obtained during rather than before treatment. Moreover, lithium is the preferred maintenance therapy option.

E) INCORRECT:

Metabolic side effects, such as dyslipidemia, are common in second generation antipsychotics, which can be used as alternative agents in the long-term treatment of bipolar disorder. However, lipid studies are obtained during rather than before treatment. Moreover, lithium is the preferred maintenance therapy for bipolar disorder.
questions.hint: This patient has an elevated mood, pressured speech, and flight of ideas, strongly suggesting an acute manic episode of bipolar disorder, for which long-term treatment with lithium is indicated.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with bipolar I disorder and hypertension comes to the office because of a 2-week history of increased thirst, urinary frequency, and sleep disturbance. He says that he now drinks up to 30 cups of water daily. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Examination shows decreased skin turgor. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 149 mEq/L, a potassium concentration of 4.1 mEq/L, and an elevated antidiuretic hormone concentration. His urine osmolality is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic polydipsia (PP) can occur during an acute bipolar psychosis and would present with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality levels, all of which this patient has. However, water intoxication from PP would cause hyponatremia and low serum osmolality levels, due to the dilutional effects, and subsequently low ADH levels. Furthermore, patients with PP would not have features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor).

B) CORRECT:

Increased serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in a patient with features of diabetes insipidus is suggestive of a nephrogenic cause. Nephrogenic DI is the most common complication of long-term use of lithium, the first-line mood stabilizer for patients with bipolar disorder. Lithium is believed to cause nephrogenic DI by interfering with ADH signaling in the collecting duct cells, which results in reduced expression of water channel aquaporin-2 in these cells.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

C) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Destruction of the posterior pituitary gland or the hypothalamic stalk by a large pituitary tumor can result in features of diabetes insipidus. However, this would lead to decreased ADH levels, indicating central diabetes insipidus, rather than increased ADH levels, suggesting nephrogenic DI, as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for both small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung. SCLC can cause high ADH levels due to SIADH, but patients with SIADH would have hyponatremia and a high urine osmolality. Polydipsia, polyuria, hypernatremia, and a low urine osmolality would not be expected. SCCs of the lung can secrete PTHrP, which can, in turn, result in hypercalcemia with subsequent neuropsychiatric disturbances and nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, the neuropsychiatric disturbance would usually be acute or subacute, unlike this patient's chronic psychiatric disorder. Moreover, this patient does not have a cough or a history of weight loss that would suggest a pulmonary malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

A tumor in the adrenal cortex can cause primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome), which may lead to hypertension and, occasionally, mild hypernatremia (145–150 mEq/L). However, on its own, primary hyperaldosteronism would not cause polyuria, polydipsia, or features of dehydration such as decreased skin turgor. Hypokalemia caused by primary hyperaldosteronism can desensitize the renal tubules to ADH and, consequently, lead to mild nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, this patient's potassium levels are normal.
questions.hint: This patient has features of diabetes insipidus (DI): polyuria, polydipsia, dehydration, hypernatremia, and decreased urine osmolality.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of altered mental status for 1 day. He has also had headaches, severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 days. He has hypertension and bipolar disorder. His medications include lisinopril, fluoxetine, atorvastatin, lithium, and olanzapine. He is somnolent and confused. His mucous membranes are dry. Neurological examination shows dysarthria, decreased muscle strength in all extremities, and a coarse tremor of the hands bilaterally. In addition to intravenous fluid administration and electrolyte supplementation, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal can be effective in the acute setting when patients ingest large amounts of certain toxic substances. However, activated charcoal does not bind to lithium; a different therapy is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is used to treat serotonin syndrome, which may develop following therapy with a serotonergic drug such as fluoxetine. Serotonin syndrome can result in an altered mental status, tremor, tachypnea, and diarrhea. However, other clinical features such as hyperreflexia, clonus, rigidity, hyperthermia, hypertension, and tachycardia would also be present. The mucous membranes of the oral cavity are usually moist (due to sialorrhea) and the pupils would be dilated. Moreover, serotonin syndrome usually occurs within 24 hours of an increase in the dose and/or the addition of a serotonergic drug; there is no history of a recent change in the patient's medications.

C) CORRECT:

Hemodialysis is indicated for the treatment of lithium toxicity in patients with an altered mental status, seizures, and/or life-threatening arrhythmias. Other indications for hemodialysis include a serum lithium concentration > 5.0 mEq/L or > 4.0 mEq/L with evidence of renal dysfunction (serum creatinine > 2.0 mg/dL). Serum lithium concentration should be measured in all patients with suspected lithium toxicity at the time of presentation and it should be repeated at close intervals (initially every 2–4 hours) to monitor the therapeutic effects of fluid administration and hemodialysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines such as diazepam may be used to treat seizures that occur in patients with lithium intoxication. This patient does not have a history of seizures; a different therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Dantrolene may be used to treat severe neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), which may occur following therapy with lithium or olanzapine. NMS can result in an altered mental status and tachypnea. However, other clinical features, such as hyperthermia, rigidity, hypertension, tachycardia, and/or diaphoresis, would also be present.
questions.hint: This patient takes lithium and has likely become dehydrated (due to severe vomiting and diarrhea for the past 2 days), which predisposes him to acute lithium toxicity. Lithium toxicity manifests with neurological symptoms (altered mental status, dysarthria, decreased muscle strength, coarse tremor). In addition, patients with lithium toxicity commonly present with gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea), which can further exacerbate dehydration.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents with progressive fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and thinning hair for the last 3 months. She has bipolar disorder and has been on lithium for 2 years. She denies medication non-adherence. Physical examination reveals coarse, dry hair and mild periorbital puffiness. Serum TSH is significantly elevated, and lithium level is within the therapeutic range. She is concerned about changes in her mood disorder management.

Heart rate
55/min

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valproate is a mood stabilizer for bipolar disorder but does not address lithium-induced hypothyroidism. The patient's symptoms and elevated TSH indicate thyroid dysfunction, not mood instability. Switching to valproate could worsen symptoms like weight gain, as it has its own side effect profile.

B) INCORRECT:

The lithium level is therapeutic, and the symptoms are consistent with hypothyroidism, not mood instability. Increasing the lithium dose would not address the thyroid dysfunction and could worsen hypothyroidism, as lithium interferes with thyroid hormone synthesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lithium-induced hypothyroidism occurs in iodine-replete individuals. High-dose iodine can trigger the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, inhibiting thyroid hormone production and worsening hypothyroidism. There is no evidence of iodine deficiency, making iodine supplementation inappropriate.

D) CORRECT:

Lithium can induce hypothyroidism by inhibiting iodine uptake and thyroid hormone synthesis, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and hair changes. The elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level, despite therapeutic lithium levels, confirms lithium-induced hypothyroidism. Levothyroxine therapy provides exogenous thyroid hormone, normalizing metabolic rate and alleviating symptoms without altering the bipolar disorder management.

Key learning point: Lithium, a common treatment for bipolar disorder, can cause hypothyroidism, leading to symptoms such as weight gain, weakness, and hair loss.

questions.text: Ten days after starting a new medication, a 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a 3-minute episode of myoclonic jerking movements and urinary incontinence. After regaining consciousness, he is amnestic to the event and appears confused. He has a history of bipolar disorder managed with lithium maintenance therapy for the past 15 years, as well as hypertension, asthma, and chronic lower back pain. His pulse is 92/min and blood pressure is 135/87 mm Hg. On examination, he has dry oral mucosa, muscle fasciculations, and a coarse bilateral hand tremor. His speech is slow and he is disoriented. Which one of the following is most likely to be the new medication that precipitated his current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Advanced acetaminophen toxicity can lead to changes in mental status due to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause myoclonic movements that may be confused for a myoclonic seizure. There is no evidence, however, that this patient consumed high doses of acetaminophen, and he does not have other features of advanced acetaminophen toxicity, such as jaundice or bleeding diathesis. Acetaminophen undergoes hepatic clearance, does not interfere with renal excretion and reabsorption of lithium, and is not known to precipitate lithium toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid overdose can cause altered mental status and myoclonic movements. However, it is unlikely to cause myoclonic seizures because it is an anticonvulsant. Additionally, valproic acid undergoes hepatic clearance and, while it inhibits other medications that are metabolized with the CYP450 system, it does not interfere with the renal excretion of lithium. Therefore, valproic acid is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity.

C) CORRECT:

ACE inhibitors, such as enalapril, cause vasodilation of the efferent arterioles and a subsequent decrease in GFR, which can lead to renal impairment. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic window, and any cause of renal impairment (e.g., chronic kidney disease, NSAID use) or volume depletion (e.g., due to diuretic therapy, cardiovascular disease) can precipitate lithium toxicity. Older patients (> 65 years of age) are particularly at risk for lithium toxicity, given their overall lower decreased glomerular filtration rate. To ensure safety, frequent monitoring of lithium levels is recommended in all patients taking lithium, particularly when starting a new medication.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors can precipitate lithium toxicity by reducing renal clearance of lithium, especially in older adults or those with impaired kidney function.

D) INCORRECT:

Concurrent use of fluoxetine and lithium increases the risk of developing serotonin syndrome, which can result in myoclonus, altered mental status, and, in severe cases, seizures. However, serotonin syndrome typically develops within hours of initiating or increasing the dose of a precipitating drug and would be unlikely in this patient, who presents 10 days after starting a new medication. Additionally, fluoxetine undergoes hepatic clearance and, while it inhibits other medications that are metabolized with the CYP450 system, it does not interfere with the renal excretion of lithium. Therefore, fluoxetine is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity.

E) INCORRECT:

Theophylline toxicity can cause neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures and tremors) and while it may exclusively manifest with neurologic symptoms, other features (e.g., tachycardia, arrhythmias) are also commonly seen. Additionally, theophylline is not routinely prescribed for asthma due to the risk of toxicity. Finally, since theophylline increases renal clearance and decreases serum concentrations of lithium, it is unlikely to precipitate lithium toxicity. This patient's symptoms are more likely to result from lithium toxicity following the prescription of more commonly used medication.
questions.hint: The introduction of a new medication alongside maintenance therapy with lithium has resulted in this patient developing lithium toxicity, which can cause myoclonic seizures, altered mental status, coarse tremors, and neuromuscular excitability.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with bipolar I disorder and hypertension comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of increased thirst, urinary frequency, and sleep disturbance. He reports drinking up to 30 cups of water daily. He has a 20-year history of smoking 2 packs of cigarettes daily. On examination, he has decreased skin turgor. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 149 mmol/L (136–146), potassium concentration of 4.1 mmol/L (3.5–5.1), and an elevated antidiuretic hormone concentration. His urine osmolality is decreased. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for both small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung. SCLC can cause high ADH levels due to SIADH, but patients with SIADH would have hyponatremia and a high urine osmolality. Polydipsia, polyuria, hypernatremia, and a low urine osmolality would not be expected. SCCs of the lung can secrete PTHrP, which can, in turn, result in hypercalcemia with subsequent neuropsychiatric disturbances and nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, the neuropsychiatric disturbance would usually be acute or subacute, unlike this patient's chronic psychiatric disorder. Moreover, this patient does not have a cough or a history of weight loss that would suggest a pulmonary malignancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Destruction of the posterior pituitary gland or the hypothalamic stalk by a large pituitary tumor can result in features of diabetes insipidus. However, this would lead to decreased ADH levels, indicating central diabetes insipidus, rather than increased ADH levels, suggesting nephrogenic DI, as seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

A tumor in the adrenal cortex can cause primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome), which may lead to hypertension and, occasionally, mild hypernatremia (145–150 mmol/L). However, on its own, primary hyperaldosteronism would not cause polyuria, polydipsia, or features of dehydration such as decreased skin turgor. Hypokalemia caused by primary hyperaldosteronism can desensitize the renal tubules to ADH and, consequently, lead to mild nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, this patient's potassium levels are normal.

D) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic polydipsia (PP) can occur during an acute bipolar psychosis and would present with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality levels, all of which this patient has. However, water intoxication from PP would cause hyponatremia and low serum osmolality levels, due to the dilutional effects, and subsequently low ADH levels. Furthermore, patients with PP would not have features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor).

E) CORRECT:

Increased serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in a patient with features of diabetes insipidus is suggestive of a nephrogenic cause. Nephrogenic DI is the most common complication of long-term use of lithium, the first-line mood stabilizer for patients with bipolar disorder. Lithium is believed to cause nephrogenic DI by interfering with ADH signaling in the collecting duct cells, which results in reduced expression of water channel aquaporin-2 in these cells.

Key learning point: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is a common adverse effect of long-term lithium therapy, resulting in polyuria, polydipsia, hypernatremia, and low urine osmolality despite elevated antidiuretic hormone levels.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).
questions.hint: This patient has features of diabetes insipidus (DI): polyuria, polydipsia, dehydration, hypernatremia, and decreased urine osmolality.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of increasing fatigue, irregular menstrual cycles, and constipation. She reports being prescribed a new medication by her psychiatrist 6 months ago but does not recall the name. Her pulse is 51/min. Neurologic examination shows delayed relaxation of the deep tendon reflexes. Which one of the following medications was most likely prescribed by the psychiatrist?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Valproate is an anticonvulsant drug that causes adverse effects that include tremor, teratogenicity, and hepatotoxicity. It does not cause bradycardia or delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, which in this patient are caused by hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Aripiprazole is a second-generation antipsychotic that causes anticholinergic and metabolic adverse effects that include constipation, irregular menstrual cycles, and in rare cases, bradycardia. It does not cause delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, which in this patient are caused by hypothyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Mirtazapine is an antidepressive drug that causes adverse effects that include weight gain and sedation. It does not cause bradycardia or delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, which in this patient are caused by hypothyroidism.

D) CORRECT:

Lithium is commonly prescribed for bipolar disorder and used as salvage therapy for major depressive disorder. Because hypothyroidism is a relatively common adverse effect of lithium therapy, patients who take this drug should obtain thyroid function tests prior to initiating treatment and regular evaluation for this condition thereafter. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index. Additional adverse effects include polyuria (due to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus), tremor, and teratogenesis.

Key learning point: Lithium is a psychiatric medication that commonly causes hypothyroidism, so thyroid function should be monitored during therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluphenazine is a high-potency, first-generation antipsychotic that causes adverse effects that include extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia. It does not cause hypothyroidism.
questions.hint: This patient's fatigue, constipation, irregular menstrual cycles, bradycardia, and delayed relaxation of the deep tendon reflexes (Woltman sign) are caused by hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the office because of increasing fatigue, irregular menstrual cycles, and constipation for 4 months. She reports that she was prescribed a new medication by her psychiatrist 6 months ago but forgot its name. Her pulse is 51/min. Neurologic examination shows delayed relaxation of the deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following medications was most likely prescribed by the psychiatrist?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mirtazapine is an antidepressive drug that causes adverse effects that include weight gain and sedation. It does not cause bradycardia or delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, which in this patient are caused by hypothyroidism.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluphenazine is a high-potency, first-generation antipsychotic that causes adverse effects that include extrapyramidal symptoms and hyperprolactinemia. It does not cause hypothyroidism.

C) INCORRECT:

Aripiprazole is a second-generation antipsychotic that causes anticholinergic and metabolic adverse effects that include constipation, irregular menstrual cycles, and in rare cases, bradycardia. It does not cause delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, which in this patient are caused by hypothyroidism.

D) INCORRECT:

Valproate is an anticonvulsant drug that causes adverse effects that include tremor, teratogenicity, and hepatotoxicity. It does not cause bradycardia or delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, which in this patient are caused by hypothyroidism.

E) CORRECT:

Lithium is commonly prescribed for bipolar disorder and used as salvage therapy for major depressive disorder. Because hypothyroidism is a relatively common adverse effect of lithium therapy, patients who take this drug should obtain thyroid function tests prior to initiating treatment and regular evaluation for this condition thereafter. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index. Additional adverse effects include polyuria (due to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus), tremor, and teratogenesis.
questions.hint: This patient's fatigue, constipation, irregular menstrual cycles, bradycardia, and delayed relaxation of the deep tendon reflexes (Woltman sign) are caused by hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because she is worried about his unusual behavior. Two weeks ago, he was promoted and is now convinced that he will soon take over the firm. He has been working overtime at the office and spends most of his nights at parties. Whenever he comes home, he asks his wife to have sex with him and rarely sleeps more than 3 hours. He has a history of a similar episode and several periods of depression over the past 2 years. He currently takes no medications. He appears impatient, repeatedly jumps up from his seat, and says, “I have more important things to do.” There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Long-term treatment with lithium is started. Which of the following parameters should be regularly assessed in this patient while he is undergoing treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Lithium, a mood stabilizer commonly used as monotherapy for both acute and long-term treatment of mild to moderate manic episodes of bipolar disorder, blocks the coupling of thyroid hormone precursors, the release of T4 and T3, and the conversion of T4 to T3. As a result, hypothyroidism is a common side effect of lithium, which is why thyroid function tests (e.g., thyroid-stimulating hormone and free T4) should be performed every 6–12 months during ongoing treatment. Lithium-induced hypothyroidism, which is often subclinical, should be treated with replacement therapy. There is usually no need to discontinue lithium therapy.

Further side effects of lithium include tremor, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, teratogenicity (in particular Ebstein anomaly), and ECG changes (e.g., T-wave depressions).

B) INCORRECT:

Regular measurement of serum aminotransferases is not necessary with lithium treatment because this drug is not known to cause liver damage. Valproic acid, which can also be used as a mood stabilizer in patients with bipolar disorder, is associated with severe hepatotoxicity. Therefore, serum liver testing prior to valproate therapy and at frequent intervals thereafter is recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Although leukocytosis is a possible side effect of lithium, this is usually clinically insignificant and does not warrant the regular measurement of complete blood count with differential. Clozapine, which is sometimes used for treatment-resistant bipolar disorder, can cause life-threatening agranulocytosis, which is why a complete blood count should frequently be obtained in patients using this drug.

D) INCORRECT:

Although lithium has been associated with hyperglycemia, this is an uncommon side effect; therefore, regular measurement of serum glucose is not recommended during ongoing treatment. Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., clozapine, olanzapine, quetiapine), which can be used to treat acute mania or as adjunctive therapy for refractory bipolar disorder, are known to cause hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia, and weight gain. Thus, fasting serum glucose should be monitored regularly in patients using this group of drugs.

E) INCORRECT:

Routine urine cultures are unnecessary with lithium treatment because this drug is not associated with urinary tract infections. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is a possible side effect of lithium as a result of interference with ADH signaling. However, a urine culture is irrelevant in diagnosing nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.
questions.hint: This patient's heightened self-esteem (convinced he will take over the firm), increased goal-directed activity (working overtime, socializing more than usual, increased libido), decreased need for sleep, and psychomotor agitation (repeatedly jumping up from his seat) are characteristic of a manic episode. His history of depression suggests bipolar I disorder, for which lithium is the preferred therapy.
